different chemical elements {{Citation

  | Fort Worth, TX publisher = Saunders College Publishing/Harcourt College
  | Publishers year = 2000 edition = 6th page = 15 isbn = 978-0-03-072373-
  | 5}} that can be separated into simpler substances by chemical
  | reactions. {{Citation last = Wilbraham first =
  | Antony last2 = Matta first2 = Michael last3 = Staley first3 = Dennis last4 =
  | Waterman first4 = Edward title = Chemistry place = Upper Saddle River, NJ
  | publisher = Pearson/Prentice Hall year = 2002 edition = 1st page = 36 isbn =
  | 0-13-251210-6}} Chemical compounds have a unique and defined chemical
  | structure; they consist of a fixed ratio of atoms
  | that are held together in a defined spatial arrangement by chemical bonds.
  | Chemical compounds can be molecular compounds held together by covalent
  | bonds, salts held together by ionic bonds, intermetallic compounds held
  | together by metallic bonds, or complexes held together by coordinate
  | covalent bonds. Pure chemical elements are not considered chemical
  | compounds, even if they consist of molecules that contain only multiple
  | atoms of a single element (such as H 2, S 8, etc.), {{Citation last = Halal first = John title = Milady's Hair
  | Structure and Chemistry Simplified publisher = Milady Publishing year = 2008
  | edition =5 isbn = 1-4283-3558-7 chapter = Chapter 8: General Chemistry
  | chapterurl =
  | http://www.wadsworthmedia.com/marketing/sample_chapters/156253629X_ch08.pdf
  | pages = 96â98
}} which are called diatomic molecules or polyatomic molecules.
